questions.question_text:
An application developer is designing an application involving secure transports from one service to another that will pass over port 80 for a request.
Which of the following secure protocols is the developer MOST likely to use?

comments.content: I believe that FTPS = 989 and 990

discussion.content:
By process of elimination answer is 
C. SSL

A. FTPS = port 22
B. SFTP = port 22
C. SSL = "is in no way tied to a single port value; in fact, as a protocol, it can be used over any transport medium, as long as that medium provides a bidirectional stream for arbitrary bytes." https://superuser.com/questions/791218/can-i-use-another-port-other-than-443-for-ssl-communication
D. LDAPS = port 636
E. SSH = port 22

I agree. This question is messed up. Considering how much you pay for these exams, the questions should go through a few layers of scrutiny imo. Anyway I think the key here is 'Which of the following secure protocols is the developer MOST likely to use?' ...and if we're all honest, what usually happens when we go about securing HTTP in 99% of cases? SSL/TLS.
SSL..I picked it right away without question. It secures http

Answer: C
Explanation:
Using HTTPS uses SSL. The initial request is made through port 80 on the server, but all subsequent communication between the client and the server uses port 443.
ONE SERVICE TO ANOTHER....wouldnt this suggest initial on 80, then session moves over to 443 to be secure? Just a thought....Lead2Pass has SSL ans correct answer also!
Answer is correct. HTTPS default port 443 can be changed to port 80

FTPS, SFTP, and LDAPS having "S" means its an extended version of an unsecured technology or a workaround implementation. This will have extra difficulty in implementation unlike SSL which is a solid implementation.

GCGA: STARTTLS allows an
encrypted version of the protocol to use the same port as the
unencrypted version
FTPS = uses SSL not SSH

the question is secure not port 80, " pass over port 80 for a request."
"Which of the following secure protocols is the developer MOST likely to use?"
port 80 no obbligatory SSL

E Question says “involving SECURE transports” “over port 80” - SSH can use port 80. 
ProxyCommand proxytunnel -q -p myserver.mydomain.com:80 -d localhost:22 
Now you can ssh pmyservername
Not (A) FTPS uses port 21 or 990 – 990 is for implicit FTPS and assumes client is using SSL) – port 21 is explicit FTPS.
Not (B) SFTP uses port 22 and SSH (SFTP itself has no dedicated port) – better than FTPS - easier to port thru firewalls.
Not (C) SSL has no assigned port so will go with the standard FTPS or SFTP ports (21, 22, 990)
Not (D) LDAPS port 389
[also: although SCP is not mentioned, SFTP and SCP go over the same port, as they both use the SSH protocol]

its in http: port 80. 
SSL : 443.. not sure if answers are correct

https://askubuntu.com/questions/107173/is-it-possible-to-ssh-through-port-80
SSL uses port 443, but SSH can use port 80. Port 80 is in the question.

comments.content: I think that solution is outside of the scope of this exam and falls more under "nerd jerry rigging" rather than a typical solution.

discussion.content:
This link is a great source of information for differences between SSL and SSH.
http://www.differencebetween.net/technology/difference-between-ssh-and-ssl/#ixzz64ol8LJKu

Yup, it is.. The question all togather does not make any sense. how would you transport data over http? Why not use FTPs or SFTP. But in any case it seems like SSL is the only answer for this question.
Isn't HTTP over SSL on port 443?

questions.question_text: Which of the following threat actors is MOST likely to steal a company's proprietary information to gain a market edge and reduce time to market?

discussion.content:
A. Competitors can also engage in attacks. Their motivation is typically to
gain proprietary information about another company.
Source: Get Certified Get Ahead
The answer is A, source: get certified get ahead pg269.

A Hacktivist launches attacks as part of an activist movement or to further a cause. An insider is anyone who had legitimate access to an organization internal resources, such as a employee of a company.
Organized crime elements are typically motivated by greed and money and often use sophisticated techniques.
I totally agree... the best answer is Opt A.
Yes I agree with you

choices.D: Implementing a unique user PIN access functions
choices.B: Installing a software-based IPS on all devices

questions.question_text: Which of the following precautions MINIMIZES the risk from network attacks directed at multifunction printers, as well as the impact on functionality at the same time?

discussion.content: An isolated system minimizes the risk from network attacks and the impact caused on functionality.

This reminds me of that episode from The Office when Dwight enforced a unique user PIN and everyone would take so long to actually use the copier, kevin kept messing up his PIN and there was a long line of employees waiting for him. This is an example of how a PIN could impact functionality.
My answer for this is Isolation
Yes, the safest thing to do is to create a VLAN only for the printers and place them all in it.

ALWAYS VLAN A PRINTER....eat this answer, move on and PASS! or dont....better for me! Also, they actually hack the network password from printers, then pivot...only allow them on that vlan...it quarantines them!

a user pin would be for access on the printer itself, so not this. MFP probably wouldn't have a hard disk so no FDE or IPS installed. Putting them on a separate VLAN would enable you to only route printing protocols to that VLAN, making them more secure

VLANs contribute to security because they enable administrators to separate hosts from each other, usually based upon sensitivity. In other words, you can assign sensitive hosts to a VLAN and control which other hosts access them through the VLAN. Since VLANs are logical (and software-based), you can control other aspects of them from a security perspective. You can control what types of traffic can enter or exit the VLAN, and you can restrict access to hosts on that VLAN via a single policy. You can also provide for increased network performance by using VLANs to eliminate broadcast domains, the same as you would with a traditional router (Mike Meyer’s CompTIA Security+ p. 297).
A. Isolate using VLANs
well... as a general rule you put MFDs on a separate vlan anyway to reduce traffic anyway and prevent pivoting.

D Question asks two things. First is which "MINIMIZES the risk from network attacks." Second is which "MINIMIZES the"... "impact on functionality." A hacker with a password cracker could easily determine a PIN, but the printer itself wouldn't function any differently if a PIN was used. A firewall would equally protect a printer whether it's on an isolated VLAN or within the primary internal network. But a PIN would add a little more protection from hackers with absolutely no impact on the functionality (not availability) of the printer. The question is concerned with functionality not availability.

comments.content: Lol .. having a user access pin would reduce the risk from a network attack and also won’t affect functionality??

discussion.content: An (MFP) multifunction printers use functions like scan to folder , email and ldap. You have to enable the appropriate ports to be able to get those functions to work. Those ports make the MFP more susceptible to attacks and are better to have them on a different network.

comments.content: MFDs, a lot of times, don't have traditional hard drives and are just embedded firmware so you couldnt do a FDE. I dont get this question either. Ive been in companies that require pins for printer access, so that was my choice...

Question also wants a solution that minimizes functionality, I guess adding the PIN reduces availability and therefore functionality. cannot install an IPS on a MFD i doubt. Isolating reduces attack surface.

discussion.content:
I have no idea why it is A. 
The only answer that makes some sense to me is FDE as it will limit attack effectiveness. Having all MFDs on a separate VLAN, how does that reduce attacks ?
Why...

questions.question_text: After an identified security breach, an analyst is tasked to initiate the IR process. Which of the following is the NEXT step the analyst should take?

discussion.content:
6 STEPS OF INCIDENT RESPONSE
Preparation
Detection & Identification
Containment
Remediation
Recovery
Lessons Learned (Documentation)

Ergo, from available options being presented, Recovery is the next step...

comments.content:
The diagram at this link helps illustrate what mad is explaining.
After Detection, Containment, Eradication and Recovery are really all grouped together as the "next step". 
https://www.infocyte.com/blog/2019/10/02/ir-planning-the-critical-6-steps-of-cyber-security-incident-response/

Preparation
Detection & Identification
Containment
Eradication (not remediation that would be the same shit as recovery)
Recovery
Lessons Learned

discussion.content:
So, in Gibson's book it says this: "Identification is the first step after hearing about a
potential incident to verify it is an incident." page 144

Anther case of COMPTIA's moronic wording of questions. Seriously, after identifying the problem, we need to identify it? I get that its the first step but the way they have worded this deliberately implies that the identification phase is already complete. This is why I am always nervous to take COMPTIA exams. It's not the content, its the trick questions.

comments.content: I agree dude, but least we know, good luck with the exam I'm taking mine tuesdat!

discussion.content:
Identification is correct. The phases of of incident response are: Prepare, Identification, Containment, Eradicate, Recovery and Lessons Learned. 
The process was to be initiated, Preparation is as straightforward as having a trained team/someone to respond which is the analyst in this case. so the next phase will be Identification which may include identifying the depth of the breach.
Identification has been done, next step considering the other options given would be Recovery. I hope people read these discussions.
These questions are so idiotically worded. It specifically says this should be the next step AFTER IDENTIFICATION of a problem, and then the answer is identification and not recovery?!? C'mon man

After an identified security breach.
I think RECOVERY because indentification is already done
Why B since the security breach has already been identified?

I don't really like that way that this question formulated. "After an identified security breach," is stated in the beginning, which implies to me that the identify step has already occurred. However, the answer is A. because they want you to show that you understand the steps. I think its not clear what they want, and selecting A. is redundant even if it is correct.

comments.content: aren't you "always" in the preparation phase?

discussion.content: my gibson book is on page 493 ... the first step in the incident response process is preparation. After identifying incident, personnel attempt to contain or isolate the problem.

You have A breach...now determine the EXACT type of Breach!! IS it APT? Is it Malware...you MUST determine the EXACT type of breach....if I am arrested for a felony, dont you need to identify exactly what I done? Probably took Twisted Tea to the head of some exam prepper for missing obvious easy questions...

This is exactly what the test is all about. word salad to trip u up and doubt yourself. IR process hasn’t been initiated yet, on the test it’ll be identification. Rlly wish these questions went thru more scrutiny.

comments.content: meaning the answer should be C since preparation is the first step in IR

discussion.content: keyword is "initiate" which means start or begin ,

comments.content:
shouldn't it be preparation then?
I seriously do not get the wording. People are accepting the answer B but it's hard to swallow.

discussion.content: Analyst has yet to initialize IR process so identification is correct.

Although the question might seem to be worded terribly, it is a typical Comptia question whose aim is to confuse. However, the question stated clearly that the analyst was tasked to INITIATE the IR process. The keyword here is INITIATE. It never said the analyst identified the breach. Someone else might have identified the breach but when the task is assigned to the analyst, following the IR process, the next step for the Analyst would be IDENTIFICATION - From the moment you become aware that an incident has occurred, it’s important to answer a few crucial questions before doing anything else. What kind of incident has occurred? Has any data been leaked or lost? What is the level of severity? This will help you choose the best course of action according to your incident response process. The main emphasis of this phase is on detecting and reporting any potential security threats. So the answer is correct!

https://resources.infosecinstitute.com/category/certifications-training/securityplus/sec-domains/risk-management-in-security/incident-response-procedures/#:~:text=Incident%20response%20is%20not%20a,cover%20the%20following%20six%20steps.

comments.content: how can it be so when the first step of IR is preparation?

discussion.content: In an organization, when an incident is suspected or even identified and then an analyst is asked to carry out the IR process. He will have to start all over by himself to confirm that truly there is an incident and what to do next after receiving the information is to get prepared. This question simply indicates that an information was passed across to him to act on. So getting prepared is the next step to take.
The fact that it say "initiate the IR plan", should mean that it is starting it. Identifying a breach doesn't mean you have identified the issue, just that you know something happened.
Analyst has been tasked with initiating the IR process. Since there is a breach, preparation won’t be there. We would go into Identification.

Just read the Q again as: After a confirmed security breach, an analyst is tasked to initiate the IR process. Which of the following is the NEXT step the analyst should take?
Then you easily get the answer as Identification !

key words initiate IR. Then you need to identify the type of breach. this almost threw me off because they used "identified a breach..." in other words they new something happened but have yet to "identify" what it was.

I agree on Identification. The only other answers that are actually part of the IR are Preparation (which won't work since we already know of the security breach) and Recovery (which is one of the last steps).
The word "identified" is probably meant to be a synonym for "detected". The analyst is tasked to "initiate" the IR process. Since the breach has already been detected, identification is next.

Just because someone else identified the breach, doesn't mean you shouldn't also identify it. Besides the analyst is tasked with "initiating" the IR process. Therefor the next step is to take the next step which is IDENTIFICATION.. given that the analyst is already prepared.

Answer: B
Keyword: "...initiate"

Yes the breach has been identified, but the IR process is not started yet. Therefore, initiation entails an identification as a first step before containment and eradication.

SANS stands for SysAdmin, Audit, Network and Security.**SANS** Incident Response Process consists of six steps:
Preparation
Identification 
Containment
Eradication
Recovery
Lessons Learned

The National Institute of Standards and Technology **NIST** Incident Response Process contains four steps:
Preparation
Detection and Analysis
Containment, Eradication, and Recovery
Post-Incident Activity

i agree with Stefanvangent - it is terribly worded. You are left with trying to read the test writer's mind in order to get the answer, also. Test questions should not be like that. It should give you all the information you need to make a logical conclusion. Of the available answers recovery is the only one that comes next in the spectrum (even though it is a couple levels down and containment should be the answer). So, Recovery is, in fact, the best answer here. If I get this question on the exam, though, I guess I'll have to go with Identification.

The analyst is tasked to initiate the IR process. So it has been identified but the process was not initiated. So he would initiate the process in the identification phase and move from then on. That is my understanding. 
If the question is asking about next tep, then I guess recovery would be the better answer.

This is a terribly worded question but... Documentation and escalation are not part of an IR so that rules both out. The question clearly says "AFTER an IDENTIFIED security breach..." so that rules out preparation because that comes before Identification, and it also rules out Identification because the security incident is already Identified. The only answer that remains is Recovery because Containment and Eradication are not listed as answers and the question also asks what to do NEXT(after Identification, (and containment and eradication))

comments.content: Breach hasn't been "identified." The breach has been detected, yes. Something has happened. So they need to identify what exactly the breach did. This is the identification process. What would they contain; Nothing, because there's been no specific identification on what happened. Also, the next step after identification is containment. So you're wrong on two fronts.

Question states - “after an identified security breach”. Not sure what you are talking about.
Also Recovery is the best option from the available options and not necessarily from an IR process perspective

Basem Basem Basem, how many times did I call you lol....It cant be identification bcuz the breach has already been identified my good man....the next stage after identifying is to recover... hope this links helps 
https://digitalguardian.com/blog/five-steps-incident-response

discussion.content:
Preparation is the first step and it happens before an incident is identified. If Containment was an answer I would have selected it. By elimination we get identification. 
It is not preparation since that should happen before an incident occurs. 
It is not recovery because it should happen after containment and eradication. 
not escalation since that is part of a Incident planning but not response. that leaves identification. 

Usually documentation but it has already been identified so it already was documented.
The security breach has already been identified, so the next step should be preparation.

comments.content: The wording is misleading, I truly believe it is Identification being the answer. The question says there was a breach that is identified. Next step would be to see what type of breach it is, what is it called so appropriate action can be taken.
no preperation (preparing for situations such as this and developing an IR plan) is way before identification.

questions.question_text: A company was recently audited by a third party. The audit revealed the company's network devices were transferring files in the clear. Which of the following protocols should the company use to transfer files?

discussion.content: Secure copy protocol (SCP) is a means of securely transferring computer files between a local host and a remote host or between two remote hosts. It is based on the Secure Shell (SSH) protocol. "SCP" commonly refers to both the Secure Copy Protocol and the program itself.

comments.content: got it, because not communicate but transfer files, then yes, SCP
So that means it's SCP? Asking for a friend...

discussion.content:
Answer: C
Explanation:
The Secure Copy Program (scp) is not discussed in the book. It is part of the SSH protocol suite and it uses port 22.

Secure Copy (SCP) is based on SSH and is used
to copy encrypted files over a network.
Secure copy...moveOn.org
why not HTTPS...it uses TLS..

comments.content: HTTPS is for securing URL, I think It got nothing to with file transmission. remember it means to secure the url(company website address).
I move a lot of stuff over HTTPS via SCCM ;). But its still fairly clear if you know the four things that SCP is the right answer.

Its questions like this that I hate. Microsoft WebDAV uses HTTP or HTTPS for moving files and can used as a replacement for FTP.

Source: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/iis/configuration/system.webserver/webdav/

“Company’s network devices transferring files”.
Why would network devices transfer files using HTTP?
SNMP is a protocol for managing network devices. It has nothing to do with file transfers.

discussion.content:
why not - SNMPv3 uses DES? if question are about network devices
SNMP allows network administrators to manage, monitor, and receive notifications of critical events as they occur on the network.
